> The BIC still had an overarching narrative: hunt-down and kill 
> Jakarta.

I'd argue against that.  To me, Jakarta was a sub plot.

  Within this, you had several sub-plots: Carl the Druid and 
> the evil magic-users, the undead fighting the slimes, Cenweith 
Manor, 
> etc.  Each one of these plots was linear (more or less), so you 
still 
> got some story told.

Actually, I did build up to securing a fairly large area.  Episodes 
3-8 all branch off from scenario #2.  It's easier to do a linear plot 
and sometimes hard to branch off.  Also, I didn't list which scenarios 
 were connected to other scenarios deliberately.  Names of characters 
get worked on when specifics get worked out.
 
The second is that a 
> lot of the levels have premises that may come off strangely: one 
> third of your army has turned -- presumably this doesn't mean your 
> squad (since you can't actually steal people from the squad), but if 
> it means simply your NPC forces, then the level will probably wind 
up 
> being pretty easy (2/3 of your forces + you vs. 1/3).

That is answered easily enough:  Follow the storyline instead of the 
battles.  Every time you fight in the battlefield, your army equals 
your hired troops.  Everytime you fight in the storyline, your army 
has much greater numbers than your hired troops in order to be 
realistic.
